scenario: Configure hostname 'R1' and disable DNS lookup on a new router.
explanation: Must enter privileged EXEC, then global config before setting hostname.

scenario: Set the banner MOTD to 'Unauthorized access is prohibited'.
explanation: Must enter privileged EXEC, then global config before setting banner. Use # delimiter.

scenario: Save the running configuration to the startup configuration.
explanation: Use the copy command to save the config.

scenario: Configure hostname 'Switch1' and save to flash.
explanation: Configure hostname then save to startup config.

scenario: Set the console password to 'cisco' and enable login.
explanation: Configure console password and enable login.

scenario: Configure the console with a password 'class'.
explanation: Enter the console, set the password, enable login, and exit.

scenario: Setting console password 'secret' and enabling login.
explanation: Set console password then enable login.

scenario: Configure console password with password 'admin'.
explanation: Must enter global config and then console line, before setting the password and enabling login.

scenario: Set the enable secret password to 'class'.
explanation: Set the enable secret password.

scenario: Set the enable secret to 'mys3cr3t' and the minimum password length to 8.
explanation: Configure enable secret and min-length.

scenario: Set enable secret password 'secure' and minimum password length to 10.
explanation: Configure enable secret and password length.

scenario: Configure enable secret with password 'topsecret' and minimum password length of 12.
explanation: Setting the enable secret and min password length.

scenario: Set the console password to 'cisco', enable login, then enable password encryption.
explanation: Set console password, enable login, then enable password encryption.

scenario: Configure console password and enable encryption.
explanation: Set console password, enable login, then service password encryption.

scenario: Configure line console 0 with password 'admin' and encrypt all passwords.
explanation: Configure console line, set password, enable login and encrypt.

scenario: Set console password, enable login, and then enable service password-encryption.
explanation: Must set the password before enabling password encryption.

scenario: Save the current configuration.
explanation: Use the write memory command to save the config.

scenario: Save the running configuration and verify the saved configuration.
explanation: Copy the running config to startup config, then verify the startup config.

scenario: Save the running config to startup config and display the contents of the saved configuration.
explanation: Saving the config and verifying.

scenario: Save the running configuration to NVRAM, then verify.
explanation: Saving the config to NVRAM and verifying.

scenario: Configure SSH on a router with hostname R1 and domain company.net, using 1024-bit RSA keys.
explanation: This configures SSH with a local user for authentication.

scenario: Configure SSH on a router with hostname RouterA and domain example.org, using 2048-bit RSA keys.
explanation: This sets up SSH with a different username and secret.

scenario: Configure SSH on a router with hostname SwitchB and domain network.local, using default RSA keys.
explanation: This configures SSH with default RSA key size.

scenario: Configure SSH on a router with hostname CoreRouter and domain corporate.com, using 1024-bit RSA keys.
explanation: Setting up SSH with a dedicated backup user.

scenario: Configure SSH on a router with hostname EdgeRouter and domain external.net, using 2048-bit RSA keys.
explanation: Configuring SSH for a remote access user.

scenario: Generate RSA keys for SSH on a router with hostname Server and domain example.net.
explanation: Proper order for RSA key generation.

scenario: Generate 2048-bit RSA keys for SSH on a router with hostname Device1 and domain test.org.
explanation: Ensure correct hostname and domain are set before key generation.

scenario: Generate RSA keys with 1024 modulus. Hostname is RouterX and domain is domain.com.
explanation: Domain name must precede key generation.

scenario: Generate 2048-bit RSA keys for SSH where Hostname is 'Host' and domain name is 'newdomain.net'.
explanation: Generate the keys with domain and hostname configured.

scenario: Configure the VTY lines for SSH only and set login to local authentication.
explanation: This disables telnet and enables local username/password authentication.

scenario: Configure VTY lines for SSH only with an exec-timeout of 15 minutes.
explanation: Sets an inactivity timeout for VTY sessions.

scenario: Configure VTY lines for SSH only and apply access-list 1 for incoming connections.
explanation: Secures VTY lines with an access list.

scenario: Configure VTY lines for SSH only, disable telnet and enable local authentication.
explanation: Sets VTY lines for SSH only.

scenario: Create a local user 'netadmin' with secret 'securepass'.
explanation: Creates a local user with a secret.

scenario: Create two local users: 'operator' with secret 'opsecret' and 'monitor' with secret 'monpass'.
explanation: Creates multiple local users.

scenario: Create local user 'admin' with secret 'cisco123' and privilege level 15.
explanation: Assigns privilege level to a local user.

scenario: Configure a local user 'backup' with secret 'backuppass' and privilege 7.
explanation: Creates local user with defined privilege.

scenario: Enable SSH version 2 on a router with hostname Router1.
explanation: Enables SSH version 2.

scenario: Enable SSH version 2 after configuring hostname and domain-name.
explanation: SSH version 2 enabled after setting hostname and domain name.

scenario: Configure SSH version 2 on a router after setting the hostname 'Device'.
explanation: Enables only SSH version 2.

scenario: Configure interface G0/0 with IP 10.1.1.1/24 and enable it.
explanation: Basic interface configuration.

scenario: Configure interface Serial0/0/0 with IP 172.16.1.1/30 and clock rate 64000.
explanation: Serial interface configuration with clock rate.

scenario: Configure interface Loopback0 with IP 192.168.2.1/32.
explanation: Loopback interface configuration.

scenario: Configure interface G0/1 with IPv6 address 2001:db8:2::1/64.
explanation: IPv6 interface configuration.

scenario: Configure interface FastEthernet0/0 with description 'Link to Server'.
explanation: Interface description configuration.

scenario: Configure VLAN 10 on interface G0/2 with IP 10.1.2.1/24.
explanation: Subinterface configuration for VLAN.

scenario: Configure SVI on a switch for VLAN 1 with IP 192.168.10.1/24 and default gateway 192.168.10.254.
explanation: Switch virtual interface configuration.

scenario: Configure IPv6 link-local address on interface G0/0.
explanation: IPv6 link-local address configuration.

scenario: Configure interface FastEthernet0/1 with IP 10.10.10.1/27 and a description.
explanation: IP configuration with a description.

scenario: Configure interface Serial0/0/1 as DCE with IP 192.168.3.1/30 and clock rate 128000.
explanation: Serial DCE configuration with clock rate.

scenario: Configure interface Loopback1 with IPv6 address 2001:db8:3::1/128.
explanation: Loopback interface IPv6 configuration.

scenario: Configure interface G0/3 with IPv4 and IPv6 addresses.
explanation: Dual-stack interface configuration.

scenario: Configure subinterface G0/4.20 with VLAN 20 and IP 172.16.20.1/24.
explanation: Subinterface configuration for VLAN.

scenario: Configure SVI VLAN 2 with IP 192.168.20.1/24 on a switch.
explanation: Switch virtual interface configuration.

scenario: Configure interface FastEthernet0/2 with IPv6 address 2001:db8:5::1/64 and link-local address.
explanation: IPv6 interface configuration with link-local.

scenario: Configure interface G0/5 with IP 10.1.5.1/24 and description 'Uplink'.
explanation: IP configuration with a description.

scenario: Configure interface Serial0/0/2 as DCE with IP 192.168.4.1/30 and clock rate 256000.
explanation: Serial DCE configuration with clock rate.

scenario: Configure interface Loopback2 with IPv6 address 2001:db8:6::1/64 and description 'Router ID'.
explanation: Loopback interface IPv6 configuration with description.

scenario: Configure interface G0/6 with IPv4 and IPv6 addresses, including link-local.
explanation: Dual-stack interface configuration with link-local.

scenario: Configure subinterface G0/7.30 with VLAN 30 and IPv6 address 2001:db8:8::1/64.
explanation: IPv6 Subinterface configuration for VLAN.

scenario: Secure the console line with password 'cisco' and enable synchronous logging.
explanation: This sequence configures the console line to require the password 'cisco' for login and enables logging synchronous to improve readability.

scenario: Secure VTY lines 0-4 with password 'cisco', allow only SSH, and set a 5-minute timeout.
explanation: This configures VTY lines to require the password 'cisco', limits access to SSH, and sets a 5-minute timeout for inactivity.

scenario: Configure VTY lines 0-4 to use local authentication and allow only SSH.
explanation: This configures VTY lines to authenticate against the local username database and restricts access to SSH.

scenario: Restrict VTY line access (0-4) to the 192.168.1.0/24 network using an ACL and enable local authentication.
explanation: This configures an ACL to permit traffic only from the 192.168.1.0/24 network to the VTY lines and uses local authentication.

scenario: Secure both the console and VTY lines with a password 'cisco'.
explanation: This configures both the console and VTY lines to require the password 'cisco' for login.

scenario: Configure the console to use a password, enable synchronous logging, and set a 10 minute timeout.
explanation: This sequence configures the console line with a password, timeout and synchronous logging.

scenario: Configure VTY lines to allow only telnet and use a password for authentication.
explanation: This configures the VTY lines to only allow telnet and to prompt for a password for authentication.

scenario: Configure VTY lines for SSH only, local authentication, and a 1-minute timeout.
explanation: This configures VTY to authenticate using local usernames/passwords and only allows SSH traffic, setting the timeout to one minute.

scenario: Configure an ACL to allow only 10.1.1.0/24 network access to VTY lines and use local authentication.
explanation: This allows only devices on the 10.1.1.0/24 network to access the VTY lines and requires local authentication.

scenario: Configure the console with password and VTY lines to use local authentication and allow only SSH.
explanation: Console uses line password, while VTY uses local authentication. SSH is configured for VTY.

scenario: Secure the console line with password 'router' and set a 3 minute timeout.
explanation: This sequence configures the console line to require the password 'router' for login and sets the timeout to 3 minutes.

scenario: Secure VTY lines 5-15 with password 'netadmin', allow only Telnet, and set a 10-minute timeout.
explanation: This configures VTY lines to require the password 'netadmin', limits access to Telnet, and sets a 10-minute timeout for inactivity.

scenario: Configure VTY lines 0-4 to use local authentication and allow both Telnet and SSH.
explanation: This configures VTY lines to authenticate against the local username database and allows both SSH and Telnet.

scenario: Restrict VTY line access (0-4) to the 172.16.0.0/16 network using an ACL and enable local authentication.
explanation: This configures an ACL to permit traffic only from the 172.16.0.0/16 network to the VTY lines and uses local authentication.

scenario: Secure both the console with password and VTY lines with a password 'secure'.
explanation: This configures both the console and VTY lines to require different passwords for login.

scenario: Configure the console with password, enable synchronous logging, and set a 2 minute timeout.
explanation: This sequence configures the console line with a password, timeout and synchronous logging.

scenario: Configure VTY lines to allow both telnet and SSH and use a password for authentication.
explanation: This configures the VTY lines to allow both telnet and ssh and to prompt for a password for authentication.

scenario: Configure VTY lines for SSH only, local authentication, and a 3-minute timeout.
explanation: This configures VTY to authenticate using local usernames/passwords and only allows SSH traffic, setting the timeout to three minutes.

scenario: Configure an ACL to allow only 192.168.2.0/24 network access to VTY lines and use local authentication.
explanation: This allows only devices on the 192.168.2.0/24 network to access the VTY lines and requires local authentication.

scenario: Configure the console and vty lines to use local authentication and allow only SSH to the vty lines.
explanation: Console and VTYs use local authentication. SSH is configured for VTY.

scenario: Create VLAN 20 named 'HR' and assign port Fa0/5 to it.
explanation: This configures VLAN 20, names it HR, and then assigns interface FastEthernet0/5 to that VLAN.

scenario: Create VLANs 10 (Sales) and 20 (Marketing).
explanation: This creates two VLANs, 10 and 20, and assigns them names 'Sales' and 'Marketing' respectively.

scenario: Configure GigabitEthernet0/2 as an access port in VLAN 30.
explanation: This configures GigabitEthernet0/2 as an access port and assigns it to VLAN 30.

scenario: Configure FastEthernet0/1 as a trunk port with native VLAN 99.
explanation: This configures FastEthernet0/1 as a trunk port and sets the native VLAN to 99.

scenario: Configure GigabitEthernet0/5 as a trunk port allowing VLANs 10, 20, and 30.
explanation: This configures GigabitEthernet0/5 as a trunk port and allows only VLANs 10, 20, and 30 to pass through it.

scenario: Create VLAN 50 named 'Guest' and configure FastEthernet0/10 as an access port in it.
explanation: Creates VLAN 50, assigns it the name 'Guest', then configures FastEthernet0/10 as an access port belonging to VLAN 50.

scenario: Configure GigabitEthernet0/1 as a trunk port with native VLAN 1 and allowing VLANs 100 and 200.
explanation: Configures GigabitEthernet0/1 as a trunk, sets the native VLAN to 1, and allows VLANs 100 and 200.

scenario: Configure FastEthernet0/2 as an access port for VLAN 40 and configure voice VLAN 100.
explanation: Configures FastEthernet0/2 as an access port in VLAN 40 and assigns VLAN 100 for voice traffic.

scenario: Create a router subinterface GigabitEthernet0/0.20 for VLAN 20 with IP address 192.168.20.1/24.
explanation: Creates a subinterface for VLAN 20 and assigns it an IP address.

scenario: Configure FastEthernet0/3 as an access port for VLAN 5, then configure a voice VLAN of 110.
explanation: Configures access port for VLAN 5 with voice VLAN of 110

scenario: Create VLAN 30, name it 'Engineering', and assign FastEthernet 0/15 to it.
explanation: Creates VLAN, names it, and assigns a port to it.

scenario: Configure interface GigabitEthernet0/4 as a trunk, native VLAN 50, allowed VLANs 40, 50, and 60.
explanation: Trunk configuration with native and allowed vlans.

scenario: Configure interface FastEthernet0/7 as an access port in VLAN 7, then configure voice VLAN 120.
explanation: Access port and voice VLAN setup.

scenario: Create VLAN 40 named 'Finance' and VLAN 50 named 'IT'.
explanation: Creation of two VLANs.

scenario: Create subinterface GigabitEthernet0/1.10 for VLAN 10 with IP 10.1.1.1/24.
explanation: Subinterface configuration.

scenario: Configure interface FastEthernet0/11 as access port for VLAN 20.
explanation: Basic access port configuration.

scenario: Configure GigabitEthernet0/2 as a trunk allowing VLANs 1, 5, 10, 20.
explanation: Trunk port configuration with allowed VLANs.

scenario: Create VLAN 60 named 'WiFi' and assign interface FastEthernet0/12 to it.
explanation: Creates VLAN and assigns a port to it.

scenario: Configure GigabitEthernet0/3 as trunk, native VLAN 100, allowing VLANs 50, 60, 70.
explanation: Configuring a trunk port with native VLAN and allowed VLANs.

scenario: Assign voice VLAN 130 to interface FastEthernet0/4 and assign it access VLAN 6.
explanation: Configuring voice vlan

scenario: Configure a default route pointing to next-hop 10.0.0.1
explanation: The default route is configured using 'ip route 0.0.0.0 0.0.0.0 <next_hop_ip>'.

scenario: Configure a static route to network 192.168.10.0/24 via next-hop 10.1.1.2.
explanation: The static route is configured using 'ip route <destination_network> <subnet_mask> <next_hop_ip>'.

scenario: Configure a static route to network 172.16.0.0/16 via interface Serial0/0/0.
explanation: The static route is configured using 'ip route <destination_network> <subnet_mask> <exit_interface>'.

scenario: Configure a fully specified static route to 10.20.30.0/24 via 192.168.1.1 through Serial0/1/0.
explanation: The fully specified static route is configured using 'ip route <destination_network> <subnet_mask> <exit_interface> <next_hop_ip>'.

scenario: Configure an IPv6 static route to 2001:db8:3::/64 via 2001:db8:1::2.
explanation: IPv6 static routes require 'ipv6 unicast-routing' and are configured using 'ipv6 route <destination_network> <next_hop_ipv6_address>'.

scenario: Configure a floating static route to 192.168.5.0/24 via 10.1.1.5 with an administrative distance of 10.
explanation: A floating static route is configured by specifying an administrative distance greater than the default (1).

scenario: Configure a static route to network 10.10.10.0/24 via next-hop 192.168.2.2.
explanation: Standard static route configuration using next hop IP address.

scenario: Configure a static route to network 192.168.3.0/24 via interface GigabitEthernet0/1.
explanation: Static route configuration with specifying output interface.

scenario: Configure a fully specified static route to 172.17.17.0/24 via 10.0.0.2 through Serial0/0/1.
explanation: Fullly specified static route with output interface and next hop IP address.

scenario: Configure a default IPv4 route via 192.0.2.1
explanation: Default route using quad zero notation.

scenario: Configure a static IPv6 route to 2001:db8:4::/64 via 2001:db8:2::2
explanation: IPv6 static route with next hop address.

scenario: Configure a floating static route to 172.16.1.0/24 via 192.168.10.2 with AD of 15
explanation: Floating static route with AD value to make it a backup.

scenario: Configure a static route for directly connected network 10.1.2.0/24 using exit interface GigabitEthernet 0/2
explanation: Static route to a directly connected network via output interface.

scenario: Configure static route to 192.168.5.0/24 using next hop 10.10.10.1
explanation: Simple static route configuration.

scenario: Configure a default IPv6 route using next hop fe80::1 link-local address on interface GigabitEthernet0/0
explanation: Configuring default ipv6 route.

scenario: Configure a basic DHCP pool named LAN_POOL for the 192.168.1.0/24 network.
explanation: This configures a basic DHCP pool with a network address and subnet mask.

scenario: Configure DHCP to exclude addresses from 192.168.1.1 to 192.168.1.10.
explanation: This excludes the specified IP address range from the DHCP allocation.

scenario: Configure a DHCP pool to assign DNS server 8.8.8.8 to clients.
explanation: This configures the DNS server that the DHCP clients will use.

scenario: Configure a DHCP pool with a default gateway of 192.168.1.1.
explanation: This sets the default gateway for DHCP clients.

scenario: Configure a DHCP pool with a domain name of example.com.
explanation: This configures the domain name for DHCP clients.

scenario: Configure a DHCP pool with a lease time of 3 days.
explanation: This configures the lease time for DHCP clients.

scenario: Configure an interface to act as a DHCP relay agent, forwarding requests to server 10.1.1.100.
explanation: This configures the interface to relay DHCP requests to the specified server.

scenario: Configure two DHCP pools: LAN_POOL for 192.168.1.0/24 and WLAN_POOL for 192.168.2.0/24.
explanation: This creates two separate DHCP pools for different networks.

scenario: Configure a DHCP pool named VOICE with network 192.168.3.0/24 and default gateway 192.168.3.1.
explanation: Configuring a DHCP pool with network and default gateway.

scenario: Configure DHCP pool DATA with DNS server 8.8.4.4 and lease time of 1 day.
explanation: Configuring DHCP pool with specific DNS and lease time.

scenario: Configure interface Serial0/0/0 as a DHCP relay agent to server 172.16.1.1.
explanation: Configuring a specific interface as a DHCP relay agent.

scenario: Configure a DHCP pool for network 10.0.0.0/24, excluding the first 10 addresses.
explanation: Configuring a DHCP pool for a new network, with exclusion of addresses.

scenario: Configure DHCP pool with network 172.16.0.0/24, gateway .1, and domain name internal.net.
explanation: Configuring DHCP pool with network, gateway and domain name.

scenario: Configure a DHCP pool with a lease of 7 days and a DNS server of 1.1.1.1.
explanation: Configuring the DHCP pool with specific lease and DNS settings.

scenario: Configure GigabitEthernet0/1 as a DHCP relay to 192.168.2.100 and GigabitEthernet0/2 to 192.168.3.100.
explanation: Configuring multiple interfaces as DHCP relays to different servers.

scenario: Create standard ACL 10 to permit network 10.0.0.0/8 and apply inbound on G0/0.
explanation: This configures a standard ACL to permit the 10.0.0.0/8 network and applies it inbound on GigabitEthernet0/0.

scenario: Create extended ACL 100 to permit TCP traffic to port 80 and apply outbound on G0/1.
correct_sequence: access-list 100 permit tcp any any eq 80
explanation: This configures an extended ACL to permit TCP traffic to port 80 and applies it outbound on GigabitEthernet0/1.

scenario: Create a named standard ACL 'ALLOW_SSH' to permit host 192.168.1.1 and apply inbound on G0/0.
explanation: This configures a named standard ACL to permit a specific host and applies it inbound on GigabitEthernet0/0.

scenario: Create a named extended ACL 'BLOCK_PING' to deny ICMP traffic and apply outbound on G0/1.
explanation: This configures a named extended ACL to deny ICMP traffic and applies it outbound on GigabitEthernet0/1.

scenario: Create standard ACL 5 to permit 172.16.0.0/16 and deny all other traffic.
explanation: Standard numbered ACL that permits a specific network and denies everything else.

scenario: Create extended ACL 105 to permit HTTP and HTTPS traffic from any source to the 192.168.2.0/24 network.
distractors: access-list 105 permit tcp any any eq 80
explanation: Extended numbered ACL that permits HTTP and HTTPS traffic to a specific network.

scenario: Create a named standard ACL 'VPN_ACCESS' to permit the 10.0.0.0/8 network.
explanation: Named standard ACL that permits a specific network.

scenario: Create a named extended ACL 'NO_TELNET' to deny Telnet traffic from any source to any destination.
distractors: access-list 100 deny tcp any any eq 23
explanation: Named extended ACL that denies Telnet traffic.

scenario: Permit only SSH traffic (port 22) using standard named ACL 'SSH_ONLY' and apply to VTY lines.
explanation: Permits SSH traffic using access-class on VTY lines.

scenario: Configure ACL 20 to permit access from 192.168.5.0/24 and deny all other traffic.
explanation: Standard numbered ACL that permits a specific network and denies everything else.

scenario: Configure extended ACL 110 to deny UDP traffic to destination port 53 (DNS).
correct_sequence: access-list 110 deny udp any any eq 53
distractors: access-list 110 permit tcp any any eq 53
explanation: Extended numbered ACL that denies UDP traffic to port 53.

scenario: Create a named standard ACL 'ALLOW_MGMT' and permit only host 10.10.10.10.
explanation: Named standard ACL that permits a specific host.

scenario: Configure a named extended ACL 'BLOCK_HTTP' to deny HTTP traffic and apply inbound on interface G0/0.
distractors: access-list 100 deny tcp any any eq 80
explanation: Named extended ACL to deny HTTP traffic, applied inbound.

scenario: Apply standard ACL 1 (assuming it exists) inbound on interface GigabitEthernet0/1.
explanation: Applies existing standard ACL inbound.

scenario: Apply extended ACL 101 (assuming it exists) outbound on interface GigabitEthernet0/0.
explanation: Applies existing extended ACL outbound.

scenario: Create ACL 1 to permit host 192.168.10.10, and apply to vty lines for ssh access.
explanation: Permits host and applies it for VTY access.

scenario: Create a named standard ACL called 'ALLOW_TELNET_ONLY', permitting only telnet traffic.
explanation: Creates a named standard ACL for Telnet only traffic.

scenario: Create access-list 99 to permit IP address 172.16.5.5, and apply it inbound on GigabitEthernet 0/2
explanation: Standard ACL permitting single host, and applies it to an interface.

scenario: Create access-list 199 to deny traffic from source IP 192.168.10.10 and apply to gigabitethernet 0/3 outbound
explanation: Extended ACL that is denying a host and applying it outbound to an interface.

scenario: Create an ACL called 'BLOCK_EVERYTHING' that will deny all traffic. Then apply it inbound on GigabitEthernet 0/0.
explanation: Named ACL denying all traffic applied to an interface.
